title: I just realized. A mage gameplay update is the perfect time for spellvamp ratios.
body:
It's the most obvious thing that's years overdue.

Make it so that, much like with AP, abilities get different returns from spellvamp.
So that if you've got someone like Vladimir, who seems to be getting an update, who's a little or a lot overpowered with spellvamp, you can directly nerf the problem.
Instead of utterly destroying the champion in other, non-problematic areas like destroying their damage output.
Or, far more destructive, knocking out any potential for viability in spellvamp items in general.

As it stands?
Single target abilities get 100% of your spellvamp.
AOE ones get 33%.
If every single target ability had a 1.0 AP ratio and every AOE one had a .33 one, the game would literally be incapable of balance. So why are you leaving spellvamp in such a nonsensical state?

You've already got some ability to control how much a champion gets from the spellvamp return. I highly doubt it'd be difficult to get it to a point where every ability has its own unique ratio.
It literally can't cause problems on its own, because if you implement individual ratios, you can set them initially to what they basically are already. Whereafter you could actually do something with spellvamp and, y'know, balance it, instead of giving up and declaring it a lost cause.

There's no real downside to implementing spellvamp ratios.
At worst you get a tool to far more easily balance out spellvamp when it gets out of hand.
At best you make a stat healthy and viable for the whole cast to enjoy.
And it's the perfect time. The mage update. What could be a more perfect time to implement spellvamp ratios?

Barring between seasons, I guess.

Like, is there a single actual reason not to?

I found a bug too! Look, here it is.{{champion:121}}

The problem is they'd have to go through EVERY ability. That's take some massive time if they wanted to make them fair and "balanced". 

Granted once it was done it'd be a lot easier and only need upkeep for buffs/nerfs and new champs.

No they wouldn't.
They could leave every ability at 1.0/.33 and only modify them when problems arise or they're specifically looking at a champion.

Like, sure, it'd leave the game in a situation where most champions still can't really use spellvamp. But it'd also make it so that Riot could do something with the stat and actually solve any problems that arise.

Alright, I'm not sure where other people are getting confused, but I can try to help. _Holy Malevolence_, if this post doesn't help, please just ask me to remove it, and I will delete it.

Basically he's saying that a single stat can be added to all abilities that will by default be what it is already in the itemization: 100% or 33% return from spellvamp. This will then allow Riot to adjust the specific stats of those 5 or so champions that abuse it individually, and allow for more specific tuning on any other champions in the future. Now, it *is* true that equating spellvamp to AP ratios is a bad analogy, but there is a reason it was used, and I think I might be able to explain this. Lifesteal only applies to auto-attacks, which are most AD champions' primary damage output. Mages' primary output comes from their AP ratios. The thing is, AD doesn't have different auto-attack ratios depending on the champion, all AD is given equally to the champions that build it, and therefore, lifesteal ratios can be balanced based on items. However, since mages have different AP scalings, spellvamp is a little harder. It can't really be balanced purely on items, because each champion receives a different benefit from it. That is why _Holy Malevolence_ is suggesting that the fix be applied on the champions' end instead of the items.

Whether or not this should be done is not something I will assert. I think it would  be cool, but I am not sure how much it would help. It could even allow for mages to be given better spellvamp ratios down the line, especially on AoEs etc. But I can't really say if the benefit would be worth the effort, that isn't my call.

I literally just restated everything _Holy Malevolence_ already said, in my own words. But it looks like it could use some restating. Confusion did seem a bit rampant.

~CrimsonCobra3

Naw, seems like a good restating.
And anything that'd bring clarity is welcomed. I know damn well I'm not always the clearest individual.

For the same reason that ADCs don't get varying base modifiers of lifesteal stats. Comparing AP ratios and spellvamp makes no sense, as they correspond to two different things: sustain vs damage output. Calling spellvamp nonsensical itself lacks sense, because there is no issue with spellvamp. The issue is with those few champions whose kits synergize with spellvamp on a whole different level from everyone else. If you take the entire mage lineup and make each work a WotA into their build, most would not only NOT have a powerspike, but might in fact be hindered.

It's not a spellvamp problem. Spellvamp is fine. It's a {{champion:8}} / {{champion:69}} /whoever I'm not thinking of problem. And crapping on spellvamp mechanics for literally everyone just because a few champions abuse it is ridiculously bad balancing.

Bingo

It's like rageblade. RB isn't the problem. It's the 4-5 champs that are to good with it. It's balanced or mediocre on everyone else.

But the suggestion made by the OP completely solves the "spellvamp abuse" problem. This was brought up in the board about Vlad's "mid year mage update" - the fact that Vlad's existence essentially forced Riot to nerf spellvamp to the point that it is relatively useless on anyone but Vlad, Cassiopeia, and Akali. Riot Stashu said that they planned to change Vlad so he can't abuse spellvamp as much (which might let them buff spellvamp again), but that's really just a "band-aid solution". 

This suggestion provides an easy way to keep spellvamp viable for ALL champions and bring the "abusive" champions down to healthy levels. With the example of rageblade, Riot could nerf the 4-5 "abusive" champions so they are no longer oppressive, but then those champions would likely be useless without rageblade - forcing them to build it if they wanted to be viable and impactful. On the other hand, they could nerf rageblade, but that would probably end up making the item itself useless (similar to what happened with spellvamp).

Adding in a "spellvamp ratio", as suggested by the OP, means spellvamp will affect every champion differently. It would be like adding a "rageblade effectiveness" stat (just as an example) to each champion. Rather than nerfing the champions' power, having to wait for a major update to change abilities, or nerfing the stat across the board, spellvamp's effectiveness could be tailored to each champion. 

"Is spellvamp more effective on this champion than is healthy? Or does it not fit thematically on them? Ok, we'll lower it's effectiveness for that champion's abilities!" Or "Does this champion need help with their survivability? But we don't want them to be more tanky? Well, we could improve their spellvamp ratios so they can survive longer under certain conditions!"

Bam! Easy way to regulate spellvamp while still keeping it viable for most champions. Although, having a separate ratio for every ability might be a bit much - but at least having an individual ratio for each champion would make a huge difference and add another "lever" (as Riot likes to say) to help balance the game.

Except with ranged AD's, it's a static lifesteal stat for a static damage stat.
Autoattacks are all, essentially, the exact same thing. Thus applying a uniform regeneration stat to autoattacks makes sense. It's a round peg for a round hole.
Abilities, on the other hand, vary wildly. It's why AP effects them differently wherein AD effects autoattacks basically the same way in every case.
Trying to apply a uniform regeneration stat to a heavily varied group of abilities doesn't make sense. It's a round peg for a square hole.

Thing is, yes.
Certain champions benefit from spellvamp on a different level from everyone else.
In fact, there's something of a gigantic tier system involved. You've got champions like Akali, Vlad, and Cass in tier one.
Malzahar, Rumble, let's say Morde in tier two.
Morgana and Singed in tier three.
And so on and so forth until you get absolute shite tier with champions like Orianna.

If you "Fixed" Vladimir and Cassiopeia, you'd simply end up bringing up a different tier of champions who still use spellvamp far better than the rest of the cast.
Without adding ratios, there's simply no way to ever reach parity. There will always be that small minority of champions who ruin spellvamp for everyone else.

Y'know, unless you add spellvamp ratios.
Then you'd be able to bring down the high and bring up the low. Odds are it'd never be perfect, but with spellvamp ratios, you'd be able to actually balance the stat.

Also, this is in no way "Crapping on spellvamp mechanics". It's a change that, quite literally, could only be positive. The worst case scenario? Nothing changes.

It would be a hassle to program it for every damaging spell  in the game. It would be a lot easier to leave how the stat works, and create less than 10 exceptions. Also, if cass is tier 1, then vlad should be god tier.

It'd probably be easier to make a system to freely adjust it than it would be to brute force ten exceptions, m'thinks.
And a lot better for the long term.

they could cap the maximum possible healing of vlad . 
problem solved , easy .
and please buff the spellvamp runes (3.33% would be good instead of 2)

I just feel like this adds unneeded complexity in a place where only two items give this specific stat. Sure there are runes and masteries, but these come up little enough to where not much would feel different after the change.

The reason there are only two items with spellvamp is because it gets abused so heavily by just 2 or 3 champions. It makes a HUGE difference on them, while providing little to no benefit for other mages (or any other class). 

Imagine if all abilities had 100% AP ratios - There would likely be fewer items that gave AP and all AP items would definitely give less AP. It would be extremely unhealthy because of AOE, DoT, and short CD abilities. If abilities had spellvamp ratios, then more items could be given spellvamp to distinguish them from the others because there wouldn't be the risk of Vlad building up to 100% spellvamp and becoming an immortal demon...

For instance, Zhonya's is the "defense AP item" (lots of AP, some armor, and it's passive). It could include some spellvamp as well so that it feels a little better as a defensive purchase (to give it more "presence" while the passive is on cooldown - like how Luden's Echo has bonus movespeed). It would open up many more options for items that just can't happen now.

Are there ANY other stats that are only given by 2 items? I think that in itself shows that something needs to change with spellvamp. It would be like having lifesteal or critical strike chance only be given by 2 items. Or - this might be more similar to spellvamp - have 2 items that provide Energy or Energy/5 - basically useless stats except for the 4 (?) champions who use them. 

Hmmm... I suppose with that logic, another solution would be to remove spellvamp as an "obtainable" (through items, runes, and masteries) stat and just add it to the abilities of champions who "want" it thematically or for gameplay reasons.

But I like the first option better :)

I'm just not so convinced. I feel like riot is taking the less conplex route and reviewing the interaction between spell vamp and Vlad's kit. Since he is the biggest abuser by far, spellvamp will be buffed for everyone's benefit. We'll just have to see how champs like rumble do afterwards though.

I think a simpler change would just have the stat be more effective on champs that use mana. Would be interesting mechanically as well, instead of just putting it into every ability in the game

Oh, I'm pretty sure Riot won't do much more with spellvamp than adjust how Vlad interacts with it - at least for the mage update. Although they have mentioned that something will be done specifically with WotA and Gunblade, so maybe just a general percentage buff once Vlad is reigned in? 

I agree that it will definitely be easier to limit the changes to that, but... There just seems like so much potential that could come out of it. I CAN DREAM!!!
Technically, the only item in the game to give the Spell Vamp stat is Revolver. Both WotA and Gunblade don't give _actual_ Spell Vamp. Just something I found interesting.
A Rioter stated that they intend on reworking Spellvamp along with the Ryze rework
Hope {{champion:25}} is ok afterwards. Her Passive is just spell vamp

"There's no real downside to implementing spellvamp ratios"

Except of course that it's a ridiculously massive undertaking that will probably turn the game's balance on its head.  When X champion's winrate spikes after, how do you know whether to nerf their damage ratio, their vamp ratio, either base, or the spell vamp itemization?  And, given Riot's recent track record on double nerfing (itemization + kit), you can all but guarantee the change will get some champs nerfed into oblivion.  

I seriously challenge the opinion that slapping a new ratio on every damaging spell is going to "far more easily balance out spellvamp when it gets out of hand".  Under such a system, the stat is going to actually perform *less* consistently, based on how far ahead you are.  The current implementation, for all its faults, at least largely scales from the base damage amount of the spell, which remains more predictable both throughout the course of a game and from game to game (whether the purchaser gets behind or stupidly fed).

How will it perform less consistently? It will behave exactly the same as it does now - the only difference will be how effective it is on certain abilities. Right now, every ability essentially has a 100% spellvamp ratio, except for AoE abilities, which have a 33% ratio. So, if you have 15% spellvamp, you get either 15% or 5% spellvamp depending on the type of ability you use. 

The idea we're talking about here is to have every ability have a separate ratio - so, one ability has a 50% ratio (7.5% actual spellvamp if you got 15% from items), another has a 75% ratio, etc. It's the same concept as what we have now, but it can be tailored to each champion and ability specifically. It will scale exactly the same throughout the game. It doesn't matter how far ahead you are, the spellvamp doesn't magically become more effective for you than it was ten minutes before.

'Cept it probably wouldn't be a large undertaking at all. Mechanically, they should already have most of the tools in place to get it done really easily.
In terms of long term balance, they wouldn't even need to meticulously make sure every champion can use spellvamp. They could put most of the cast at 1.0 for single target and .33 for AOE.
Effortless, and literally incapable of causing any problems.

When a champion's winrate spikes, you look at their gameplay and what items boost their winrate. If they get a significantly higher winrate with spellvamp items, or you can tell it's their level of sustain....
Two things that are pretty easy to take note of...
Then it's probably spellvamp.
It's usually pretty clear cut.

Under such a system, it literally wouldn't be any different than it is now unless Riot went to specifically balance individual champions. If implemented even half competently, which shouldn't be difficult in the least, it'd do nothing but increase consistency.
And it'd still scale roughly the same amount of the spell's base damage.

That seems overly complicated and would increase the game knowledge requirement. It would be easier to alter the abilities of individual champions that abuse the stat. 

Alternatively, make spellvamp scale off of AP rather than damage dealt? Not sure it would work, but another way of treating the stat.

Doing this would make it possible to alter the abilities of individual champions who abuse the stat.
It'd actually decrease the game knowledge requirement. As of now, you have to be very familiar with the game to have any idea what champions spellvamp's even slightly worth getting on. If they added spellvamp ratios and properly balanced it, that wouldn't be necessary. You'd be able to pick up a champion and be pretty sure that, regardless of just how, spellvamp's at least not an utter waste of a stat to pick up.

And having it just scale off AP doesn't take into account, say, cooldown. Suddenly Karthus and Evelynn are super ridiculous while any champ with sizable cooldowns just can't use the stat whatsoever.

To be fair spellvamp is useful on everyone, its just that some champs are more liable to be blown up before getting any health back. 

Also, making spellvamp strong might go against Riot's current design philosophy. Mages are meant to be countered (or at least able to be countered) by burst and assassins. Imagine how annoying it would be for Zed to jump on a Veigar in jungle, drop everything on him as an assassin should, and then fail to kill him because Veigar's single target ult would heal him for 500-1000 hp. And this is for a champ that spellvamp is comparatively weak on.

That said, I agree the stat should be revisited by Riot. I just am not convinced your solution is viable.

I feel like any Veigar who can pull off the necessary timing for that deserves the victory. And would be better off using Zhonyas.

And, I agree. Mages should be countered by burst.
Sustain only really saves you from harass. I'll be frank, as an assassin player, I find that an enemy having sustain doesn't make it any more difficult for me to take them out.

The timing would honestly be pretty easy.  You could just cast R pretty much immediately - Zed uses his combo immediately, and there's a full 2 seconds until death mark finishes.

Though... that's really arguing semantics at this point.

Of course, the real problem is that lifesteal/spellvamp style sustain options really are meant to counter sustained damage offensives, not burst.  Lifesteal does this just fine, because it works on autoattacks, which is inherently also a sustained damage method.  Spellvamp just doesn't accomplish this well - it's attached to what is inherently a burst damage method (abilities), and so returns burst health.

(Of course, this is all assuming that the 'sustained damage' in the game wasn't so infinitely high that lifesteal hardly even matters against it... but I digress.)

Honestly, I'd love for AP to get a better spellvamp, or really... something.  AD just gets so many cool mechanical 'toys' - attack speed, crit strike, lifesteal - and AP really only gets.... AP and more AP.  But unfortunately, I just don't have a good solution for spellvamp as is, and I'm not sure that ratios would fix the problem.
Turn it into a sustain version of Luden's echo, not all champs can take Luden's but it has a healthy amount of champions as it has the same values at similar periods of times.

> [{quoted}](name=Meddler,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=vZKZprwH,comment-id=0000,timestamp=2016-03-17T17:00:39.152+0000)
>
> We'll be looking to adjust CDR, Mana and MP5 on AP items as our primary focus, **with some potential side changes to things like the Revolver/WotA/Gunblade line**. Overall scope of item changes will almost certainly be noticeably smaller than the preseason so this will be much more about adjustments to existing items than adding new ones.

Well,it pretty heavily implied by Meddler here that they're going to work spell vamp to some degree.It could be something else,but {{item:3145}} {{item:3152}} & {{item:3146}} all have spell vamp in common.I mean why would they work on the whole Revolver line if they're not going to work on the one thing they have in common?It has to be the spell vamp.

Personally, I think this would be WAY TOO COMPLICATED, not to mention a ton of work to hook this up to a gigantic majority of abilities in the game, and a really weird, unnecessary, and nitpicky tool considering how few champions actually get spell vamp. This might be reasonable as just part of a complete overhaul of spell vamp including new items, having spell vamp added to old items, and having the numbers of existing spell vamp items entirely redone.

Alternatively, spell vamp could be removed from the game easily, with only some compensation given to Vladimir (Who I think is up for a minor rework anyway) and some changes to Akali's passive (which would give her more freedom in build paths and possibly make her assassin playstyle more viable compared to the metagolem tank build). 

Not that I'm an expert, but I really feel like adding "heals for 0 (+0) % of damage done" to every single ability description in the game would hinder understanding to a more meaningful degree than having about 600 tiny levers to adjust spell vamp would make it an interesting stat.

'Cept it'd probably be rather simple and something of a small amount of work since, y'know, they already have the baseline in place and it shouldn't take much to modify what's already there.
It's not weird considering the game's current usage of ratios of all types. 
It's pretty damn necessary considering how problematic spellvamp often is specifically because it doesn't have something like this to balance it properly.
And... Nitpicky? Dunno what you mean by that, but one of the problems is specifically that only a few champions can use it, because if it was any more powerful it'd be way too powerful on them while being average at best on everyone else.

They could remove it, but.... Why? It doesn't inherently cause problems, like at least one other stat, it's just something they've never bothered putting proper infrastructure in place to balance.

And knowing exactly how much it heal probably wouldn't be very helpful if the stat's still literally not worth getting on 99% of the cast.

I guarantee you are VASTLY underestimating the amount of work it would take to make this change. It would literally require Riot to recode every single damage-dealing ability in the game other than the ones that don't count as spell damage (mostly the ones that count as auto attacks instead), as well as change the description for every single one of those abilities, and they probably don't have spell vamp hooked up in the same way as other stats so they'll have to recode spell vamp itself as well, and from past experience the chance that one of those hundreds of things that are changed will cause a major bug somewhere seemingly unrelated is pretty damn high.

After the basic implementation, by your suggestion the resulting balance change is... nothing, because trying to adjust all of those numbers at once would be even more work so after everything else they would just leave the new ratios at exactly the same values that they effectively are. Then, if they end up deciding that they actually do want to make changes, they're still stuck with hundreds of new numbers that they can change. What would your suggestion be then? Reduce Vladimir's ratios so that every other AP champion can build spell vamp and take over his niche as "sustain mage"? INCREASE Vladimir's spell vamp ratios while reducing his strength elsewhere to solidify his identity while limiting his build paths? Just crank up the ratios on random champions until it becomes optimal to build them with lower damage in exchange for sustain?

Or maybe it turns out that balancing spell vamp would actually require a rework of the SOURCES of the stat more than the users, since there is currently a single item in the game which a mage could reasonably buy that gives spell vamp. Of course, adding extra items as well is even more work, and needs further balancing on top of just making the concept work... and if you do all that and finally reach a state where everything is balanced? You've successfully changed some portion of mages to be sustain mages because they synergize well enough with spell vamp for it to be in their optimal build.

Alternatively, removing spell vamp means Vladimir's damage and healing can be adjusted independently , Morgana would get a real passive, and assassin Akali could be allowed to build something other than Gunblade as her first item. I don't know if that's necessarily an improvement over what we have right now, but it seems like a better result to me than what you're proposing, and requires a lot less work.

Except they already have code in place that alters the amount of spellvamp a champion can get.
Far as I can tell, worst case scenario is that they have to modify two files with additional inputs.
Those files being "Single target" and "AOE". Mind you I don't know what the code currently looks like, but that's the most difficult reasonable situation I could forsee.
Said additional input would change the spellvamp values for an ability from the standard 1.0/.33 associated with single target/AOE abilities to..... Y'know....
Whatever spellvamp ratio they so desire.
That's if they didn't build the specific returns into individual abilities already. In which case the change would literally be effortless.
And, ignoring what's reasonable and not, worst case scenario with the most ridiculous spaghetti code? Make overarching champion spellvamp ratios. Takes a tiny amount of effort and directly modifies the amount of spellvamp a champion gets from an item. Maximum amount of effort necessary?
Minimum.
This, realistically, should not be even slightly hard considering they already have the infrastructure in place.

Basically, yeah.
Once in place, at worst, they don't change anything.
But if they ever decide to actually do anything with spellvamp?
Add a new item?
Rebalance a champion to make more use of the stat?
They'd be able to do so without risking game health. Because if they tried to make spellvamp relevant and Vladimir got out of line-
Something that's happened ***multiple times***-
They'd be able to nerf his spellvamp ratios and make it work instead of scrapping the project because Vladimir breaks it.

Adding spellvamp ratios would, in fact, allow you to deal with spellvamp items without risking game health. But, realistically, no. It's not the sources, it's plainly the champions. If it was the sources, Riot would've been able to make it work by now.
They haven't. Because if you make a spellvamp item, it's going to benefit Vladimir much more than anyone else. This isn't just me making a baseless claim. It's happened multiple times before.
The reason why spellvamp is in the state it's in? Where you generally get it on Vlad and Akali, occasionally on a third champion like Cass, and would definitely never get it on anyone else?
It's because the champions who can use it do so so much better than the entire rest of the cast and there's literally no way to make an item to do anything about it.
The only thing you could **possibly** do is modify the champions.

And all the while, you'd be deleting a stat that has massive potential for improving the game because, quite frankly, you're simply too lazy to try and utilize an easy and neigh guaranteed to work solution. Yeah, it'd be easier to just scrap it.
Why not do that with everything? Kid's a bit of a problem, throw him out. Dishes are dirty? Why bother cleaning them, it's easier to throw them out. That's really a way to make the world better, eh?
Just assume something's too hard without even trying and, instead of fixing things, throw them out.
I mean, it's always two things. A) Clarity and B) workload. If they had people to do it and had a good idea on how to implement it, they would.

I just wonder if they've even come across the idea before.
Certainly never heard any reasons from Riot as to why they haven't.

It's been called for at a decent pace over the years. Everyone knows that spell vamp isn't a good analogue to life-steal, and many people would like it to be.

BUT, I also am not sure that it's the right way to go... I mean, if it were priced right, it might work, but it just doesn't fit in the kits of most mages the way they've been balanced in this game. It would be more work than it looks like.

yeah sure. lets add this to the list of "random largely-time-consuming stuff riot can do to make league better"

now, back to focusing on the REAL issues, plz rito
It's not necessary for spellvamp to be viable on all mages, some can benefit more from it some less just like with items.

They might not want to deal with spellvamp during the immobile mage update because spellvamp is good on a bunch of other champions. There are mobile mages like Ahri, Kassadin, and LeBlanc plus other champions with a bunch of damage from abilities like Maokai and Zac that can use spellvamp if it is stronger/more available.

I think spellvamp is probably somewhere on Riot's list of things to deal with, but I wouldn't be surprised if we don't see any changes with it until preseason 7.
Ahri's passive is flat scaling per level + .09 AP. I don't think Spell Vamp would break her. I'd be more concerned about Morgana's 15% passive Spell Vamp.
I wasn't really talking about Ahri's passive. I just think what the OP is suggesting (tuning spellvamp for all mages) is outside the scope of the immobile mage update.

This is a great suggestion. If either this or the idea I posted for a cap is implemented I'm sure spell vamp could make a return. Perhaps even both? Who knows?

Shameless self-link: [Spell Vamp Cap](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/lpbNLbs5-spell-vamp-sucks-on-any-mage-that-doesnt-abuse-it-lets-fix-that)
The reason AOE spellvamp is 33% percent so you don't heal all of the damage you deal in a 5 man nunu ult or a spell like that.
If Mage update won't solve main issure of good itemisation for mages (or at least on par with ADs), then fuck it, I'm out.

{{item:3152}} Just gives 15% spellvamp.
